title: Pre-K Activities
description: A cozy place to begin exploring numbers and shapes

level1.title: Number Awareness & Counting
level1.goal: Children understand that numbers have names and represent 'how many.'

bigIdea.text: This level is about learning that numbers have names and mean "how many." Counting is a touch-and-say skill: touch each thing once, say one number once, then stop and notice the total.

bullets: Your child touches items one-by-one (no skipping, no double counting).
After counting, they can answer "How many?" without recounting.
They recognize a few numerals (0‚Äì5) in daily life (signs, books, buttons).
They understand zero as "none" (an empty basket is still a real amount).

games.name: Game A (core idea): "Touch & Count"
games.description: Put 5‚Äì10 small objects in a row (buttons, grapes, blocks). Have your child touch each one while counting out loud. At the end ask: "How many are there?" Then mix them and count again.

games.name: Game B (everyday version): "Number Hunt Walk"
games.description: Pick one target number (like 3). Walk around the home and find it in books, clocks, remote controls, or labels. Each time you find it, count 3 steps or 3 claps together.

searches: counting objects one to one correspondence for preschool

level2.title: Subitizing & Quantity
level2.goal: Children can see 'how many' without counting one-by-one.

bigIdea.text: Subitizing means seeing "how many" at a glance (especially 1‚Äì3), without counting. This grows from patterns (dice dots, dot cards, egg cartons) and quick, playful peeks.

bullets: Your child can say "2!" or "3!" quickly when they see a small group.
They can match a dot pattern to a number word (like dice faces).
They understand the quantity stays the same when items move around.
They use math words naturally: more, same, fewer.

games.name: Game A (core idea): "Quick Peek"
games.description: Show 1‚Äì3 objects for 1 second (cover with a cup or your hand). Ask: "How many did you see?" Reveal and count together to check.

games.name: Game B (second representation): "Same Number, New Shape"
games.description: Place 3 coins in a line. Ask "How many?" Then rearrange into a triangle. Ask "How many now?" Let your child prove it by counting (same number, different layout).

level3.title: Number Relationships
level3.goal: Children see that numbers are made of smaller parts.

bigIdea.text: Numbers are made of smaller parts. In Pre-K, we do not need formal addition‚Äîjust playful "splits" like 3 can be 2 and 1, or 1 and 2. This part‚Äìwhole feeling becomes the foundation for later arithmetic.

bullets: Your child can split a small group into two piles in more than one way.
They can show a number on two hands (like 4 as 2 and 2, or 3 and 1).
They can reason about a hidden part ("Some are under the cup‚Ä¶").
They begin using language like "parts" and "all together."

games.name: Game A (core idea): "Hide & Find"
games.description: Put 5 small objects on the table. Cover some with a cup. Show what is left and ask: "How many are hiding?" Reveal and count to check.

games.name: Game B (second representation): "Two-Hand Splits"
games.description: Call a number 1‚Äì5. Your child shows it using two hands in any way (for 5: 5+0, 4+1, 3+2‚Ä¶). Switch roles and copy each other's splits.

level4.title: Comparing & Change
level4.goal: Children understand more, less, same, add one, take one.

bigIdea.text: This level builds the feeling of more / fewer / same, and how a set changes when you add one or take one. The goal is confident math language and noticing change, not speed.

bullets: Your child can tell which group has more (sometimes without counting).
If groups are close, they compare by matching in pairs ("one for you, one for me").
They understand "one more" and "one less" as a small change.
They can make two groups the same by adding or removing items.

games.name: Game A (core idea): "One More / One Less Tower"
games.description: Build a small tower (3‚Äì6 blocks). Ask: "What is one more?" Add one block and count. Then: "What is one less?" Remove one block and count.

games.name: Game B (everyday version): "Make It Fair"
games.description: Put snacks in two bowls (one has more). Ask your child to make them the same by moving one snack at a time. Count both bowls to celebrate when they match.
